trans-unit.source: Windows Authentication and Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server
trans-unit.target: Windows Authentication and Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server

trans-unit.source: This is the Azure Multi-factor authentication page that will assist in deploying Windows Authentication and Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server.
trans-unit.target: This is the Azure Multi-factor authentication page that will assist in deploying Windows Authentication and Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server.

trans-unit.source: Windows Authentication and Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server
trans-unit.target: Windows Authentication and Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server

trans-unit.source: The Windows Authentication section allows the administrator to enable and configure Windows authentication for one or more applications.
trans-unit.target: The Windows Authentication section allows the administrator to enable and configure Windows authentication for one or more applications.

trans-unit.source: The following is a list of things to keep in mind prior to setting up Windows Authentication.
trans-unit.target: The following is a list of things to keep in mind prior to setting up Windows Authentication.

trans-unit.source: reboot is needed before the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication for Terminal Services will be in effect.
trans-unit.target: reboot is needed before the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication for Terminal Services will be in effect.

trans-unit.source: If ‘Require Azure Multi-Factor Authentication user match’ is checked and you are not in the user list, you will not be able to log into the machine after reboot.
trans-unit.target: If ‘Require Azure Multi-Factor Authentication user match’ is checked and you are not in the user list, you will not be able to log into the machine after reboot.

trans-unit.source: Trusted IPs is dependent on whether the application can provide the client IP with the authentication.
trans-unit.target: Trusted IPs is dependent on whether the application can provide the client IP with the authentication.

trans-unit.source: Currently only Terminal Services is supported.
trans-unit.target: Currently only Terminal Services is supported.

trans-unit.source: This feature is not supported to secure Terminal Services on Windows Server 2012 R2.
trans-unit.target: This feature is not supported to secure Terminal Services on Windows Server 2012 R2.

trans-unit.source: To secure an application with Windows Authentication, use the following procedure.
trans-unit.target: To secure an application with Windows Authentication, use the following procedure.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server click the Windows Authentication icon.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Server click the Windows Authentication icon.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Windows Authentication</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Windows Authentication</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Check the Enable Windows authentication checkbox.
trans-unit.target: Check the Enable Windows authentication checkbox.

trans-unit.source: By default, this box is unchecked.
trans-unit.target: By default, this box is unchecked.

trans-unit.source: The Applications tab allows the administrator to configure one or more applications for Windows Authentication.
trans-unit.target: The Applications tab allows the administrator to configure one or more applications for Windows Authentication.

trans-unit.source: Select a server or application – specify whether the server/application is enabled.
trans-unit.target: Select a server or application – specify whether the server/application is enabled.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: Click Add…
trans-unit.target: Click Add…

trans-unit.source: button.
trans-unit.target: button.

trans-unit.source: The Trusted IPs tab allows you to skip Azure Multi-Factor Authentication for Windows sessions originating from specific IPs.
trans-unit.target: The Trusted IPs tab allows you to skip Azure Multi-Factor Authentication for Windows sessions originating from specific IPs.

trans-unit.source: For example, if employees use the application from the office and from home, you may decide you don't want their phones ringing for Azure Multi-Factor Authentication while at the office.
trans-unit.target: For example, if employees use the application from the office and from home, you may decide you don't want their phones ringing for Azure Multi-Factor Authentication while at the office.

trans-unit.source: For this, you would specify the office subnet as Trusted IPs entry.
trans-unit.target: For this, you would specify the office subnet as Trusted IPs entry.

trans-unit.source: Click Add…
trans-unit.target: Click Add…

trans-unit.source: button.
trans-unit.target: button.

trans-unit.source: Select Single IP if you would like to skip a single IP address.
trans-unit.target: Select Single IP if you would like to skip a single IP address.

trans-unit.source: Select IP Range if you would like to skip an entire IP range.
trans-unit.target: Select IP Range if you would like to skip an entire IP range.

trans-unit.source: Select Subnet if you would like to specify a range of IPs using subnet notation.
trans-unit.target: Select Subnet if you would like to specify a range of IPs using subnet notation.

trans-unit.source: Enter the subnet's starting IP and pick the appropriate netmask from the drop-down list.
trans-unit.target: Enter the subnet's starting IP and pick the appropriate netmask from the drop-down list.

trans-unit.source: Click the OK button.
trans-unit.target: Click the OK button.
